org.gearvrf.io.cursor3d

Class IoDevice

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.io.cursor3d.IoDevice

  • public class IoDevice
extends java.lang.Object
    An IoDevice controls the position of the Cursor.

    To add support for a new hardware device to control a Cursor extend this class and implement a custom IoDevice. Call setPosition(float, float, float) and (KeyEvent) from the new class for changing the position of the Cursor and sending KeyEvents to the Cursor respectively. Each IoDevice is identified by a unique set of vendorId, productId and deviceId.

    • Constructor Detail

      • IoDevice

        protected IoDevice(java.lang.String deviceId,
                   int vendorId,
                   int productId,
                   java.lang.String name,
                   java.lang.String vendorName)
        Create a new IoDevice. Call this from a subclass constructor.

        Each IoDevice is identified by a unique set of vendorId, productId and deviceId, so make sure that all IoDevices you create are unique. The vendorId, productId and deviceId you pass in here should match the values specified in the io.xml for the particular IoDevice. This constructor assumes that the hardware device associated with the IoDevice is already connected. An IoDevice created using this constructor will be ready to be attached to a Cursor. To create an IoDevice whose hardware device is not connected at initialization use IoDevice(String, int, int, String, String, boolean).

        Parameters:
        deviceId - deviceId of the IoDevice. This differentiates multiple devices from the same vendor with same productId and vendorId.
        vendorId - vendorId of the IoDevice.
        productId - productId of the IoDevice.
        name - name of the IoDevice. This is used to display the name of the IoDevice to the User.
        vendorName - name of the vendor for the IoDevice

      • IoDevice

        protected IoDevice(java.lang.String deviceId,
                   int vendorId,
                   int productId,
                   java.lang.String name,
                   java.lang.String vendorName,
                   boolean isConnected)
        Create a new IoDevice. Call this from a subclass constructor.

        Each IoDevice is identified by a unique set of vendorId, productId and deviceId, so make sure that all IoDevices you create are unique. The vendorId, productId and deviceId you pass in here should match the values specified in the io.xml for the particular IoDevice.

        Parameters:
        deviceId - deviceId of the IoDevice. This differentiates multiple devices from the same manufacturer with same productId and vendorId.
        vendorId - vendorId of the IoDevice.
        productId - productId of the IoDevice.
        name - name of the IoDevice. This is used to display the name of the IoDevice to the User.
        vendorName - name of the vendor for the IoDevice
        isConnected - true is the corresponding hardware device is connected at initialization. false if the hardware device is not connected at initialization. The setConnected(boolean) call can be used to indicate the hardware device connection later.

      • setEnable

        protected void setEnable(boolean enable)
        Sets the state of the IoDevice to value of enable.

        This method is called with false when the IoDevice is not being used and true when the IoDevice is being used. By default the value is set to true until a setEnable(boolean) with a false value is called.

        Parameters:
        enable - Enabled value true or false

      • isEnabled

        protected boolean isEnabled()
        Returns the state of the IoDevice if enabled or not. By default the value is set to true. Enabled means it is being used, and Disabled means it is not being used.
        Returns:
        true is enabled, false if disabled.

      • setPosition

        protected void setPosition(float x,
                           float y,
                           float z)
        Use this method from the IoDevice subclass to set the position of the Cursor.
        Parameters:
        x - x value of the position
        y - y value of the position
        z - z value of the position

      • setRotation

        protected void setRotation(float w,
                           float x,
                           float y,
                           float z)
        Use this method from the IoDevice subclass to set the rotation of the Cursor in quaternion terms.
        Parameters:
        w - 'W' component of the quaternion.
        x - 'X' component of the quaternion.
        y - 'Y' component of the quaternion.
        z - 'Z' component of the quaternion.

      • setVisible

        protected void setVisible(boolean visible)
        Use this method to turn on and off the visibility of the Cursor
        Parameters:
        visible - true makes the Cursor visible and false turns off its visibility.

      • getNearDepth

        protected float getNearDepth()
        Gets the value of the near depth set by the Cursor using the IoDevice. The Cursor sets the near depth to indicate the minimum distance to maintain between the origin and the cursor.
        Returns:
        the value of the near depth. By default the value is set to 0.

      • getFarDepth

        protected float getFarDepth()
        Gets the value of the far depth set by the Cursor using the IoDevice. The Cursor sets the far depth to indicate the maximum distance a cursor can travel from the origin.
        Returns:
        the value of the far depth. By default the value is set to negative Float.MAX_VALUE.

      • setKeyEvent

        protected void setKeyEvent(KeyEvent keyEvent)
        Call this from a subclass of the IoDevice to send a corresponding CursorEvent. Setting a KeyEvent with KeyEvent#ACTION_DOWN should generate a CursorEvent with CursorEvent.isActive() set to true. A KeyEvent with KeyEvent#ACTION_UP should generate a CursorEvent with CursorEvent.isActive() set to false. The exact KeyEvent can also be retrieved from the CursorEvent by calling CursorEvent.getKeyEvent()
        Parameters:
        keyEvent - the event to be set.

      • setConnected

        protected final void setConnected(boolean value)
        Use this from a subclass of IoDevice to indicate the connection status of the hardware associated with the IoDevice. For cases like a connected bluetooth or USB device this can be set true when Bluetooth or USB connection is made and false when disconnected. If the hardware device is always available the value can be set to true in the constructor and no calls to this method are required. A IoDevice is only attached to a Cursor if the isConnected value is true. On passing a false value here the IoDevice is removed from the Cursor.
        Parameters:
        value - true for connected and false for disconnected

      • isConnected

        protected boolean isConnected()
        Get connection state of the IoDevice
        Returns:
        true is the IoDevice has a connection to the associated hardware device, false if there is not connection.
